title-group.article-title: Association Between Patient‐Specific Factors and the Therapeutic Relationship in Direct Access Physiotherapy for Higher Education Students—An Observational Cross‐Sectional Study

aff.named-content: Faculty of Sport and Health Sciences

aff.institution: University of Oulu and Oulu University Hospital
Research Unit of Health Sciences and Technology
Wellbeing Services County of South Karelia
Wellbeing Services County of Central Finland

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‐commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

sec.title: Background and Purpose
sec.p: Musculoskeletal (MSK) pain is a common issue among higher education students and is often linked to poor physical function and a high psychosocial burden. In direct access physiotherapy, a patient‐centered approach is essential for building a strong therapeutic relationship. While therapist attributes are known to influence this relationship, this study aimed to explore whether patient‐specific factors, including psychosocial burden, physical function, and chronic pain, are associated with students' perception of the therapeutic relationship during their first physiotherapy visit.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This observational cross‐sectional study included 326 higher education students with MSK pain (median age: 26 years) visiting direct access physiotherapy in Finnish Student Health Service (FSHS). The Experience of the Therapeutic Relationship questionnaire was used to assess the therapeutic relationship. Patient‐specific factors included psychosocial burden and psychological distress, measured with the Short Form Örebro Musculoskeletal Pain Screening Questionnaire (ÖMPSQ‐SF) and the Mental Health Index (MHI‐5), respectively; physical function evaluated using the Patient‐Specific Functional Scale (PSFS), and chronic pain derived from the ÖMPSQ‐SF. Additional baseline data, including the level and field of study, FSHS region in Finland, and gender and age, were collected. Multiple linear regression analysis was performed to examine the associations between the therapeutic relationship and patient‐specific factors.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Psychological distress (ß = 0.30, 95% CI 0.03 to 0.58) and poorer self‐rated physical function (ß = −0.13, 95% CI −0.24 to −0.02) were associated with a more negative perception of the therapeutic relationship. However, no significant associations were found for psychosocial burden (ÖMPSQ‐SF moderate‐risk ß = −0.19, 95% CI −0.50 to 0.12; high‐risk ß = −0.02, 95% CI −0.34 to 0.30) or chronic pain (ß = 0.004, 95% CI −0.22 to 0.22).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Psychological distress and impaired physical function appear to be negatively associated with students' perception of the therapeutic relationship. Integrating these factors into patient‐centered care could potentially enhance therapeutic interactions.

p.mixed-citation: Riska, Heidi E., Jaro I.Karppinen, Mia E.Heikkala, Riku P.Nikander, Jari J.Villberg, and Arto J.Hautala. 2025. “Association Between Patient‐Specific Factors and the Therapeutic Relationship in Direct Access Physiotherapy for Higher Education Students—An Observational Cross‐Sectional Study,” Physiotherapy Research International: e70112. 10.1002/pri.70112.41006945

fn.p: Funding: This study was supported by Signe and Ane Gyllenberg Foundation (Grant 6610) and The Finnish Concordia Fund (Grant 20240372).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Prevalence of musculoskeletal (MSK) pain is high, 33% to 65%, among higher education students worldwide (Alricsson et al. 2008; Oksanen et al. 2014; Parto et al. 2023; Samarah et al. 2023). It is often linked to poor physical function and significant psychosocial burden (Bumann et al. 2020; Parto et al. 2023; Riska et al. 2024). A patient‐centered approach is considered the best practice in MSK pain management, ensuring patients feel heard, actively participate in decision‐making, and receive clear, consistent information from their physiotherapist (Pinto et al. 2012; Lin et al. 2020). This approach is particularly relevant in direct access physiotherapy, where MSK patients can see a physiotherapist without a physician's referral (Demont et al. 2021).

The strength of the therapeutic relationship, or “working alliance,” is built on goal agreement, task collaboration, and trust (Bordin 1979). This bond enhances exercise adherence (Moore et al. 2020; Vestøl et al. 2020) and improves pain outcomes (Kinney et al. 2020), making it especially crucial for patients with chronic pain, high psychosocial burden, and limited physical function (Babatunde et al. 2017; Skatteboe et al. 2017; Flynn et al. 2021; Naylor et al. 2023). To foster this relationship, physiotherapists should implement person‐centered care by aligning treatment with patient goals and promoting shared decision‐making (Vervaeke et al. 2023). The therapeutic alliance develops over time, with the initial session playing a key role in shaping rehabilitation outcomes (Krause 2024).

Therapist attributes significantly influence rehabilitation success, with therapist variability predicting outcomes more than patient differences, at least in psychotherapy (Baldwin et al. 2007; Del Re et al. 2012). Certain patient‐specific characteristics have been associated with stronger therapeutic relationships, such as younger age, female gender, and better physical function (Beneciuk et al. 2021), as well as greater patient engagement (Miciak et al. 2018). While perceived injustice, avoidance of intimacy, and avoidance of forming a bond with the therapist can weaken it (Scott et al. 2016; Paap et al. 2022). However, to our knowledge, no studies have examined patient‐specific factors associated with the therapeutic relationship in a direct access physiotherapy setting. This exploratory study aims to investigate whether psychosocial factors, pain chronicity, and self‐perceived physical function influence higher education students' perceptions of the therapeutic relationship during their direct access physiotherapy visit. We hypothesize that psychosocial factors and poorer physical function will be associated with a more negative perception of the therapeutic relationship.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This exploratory, cross‐sectional observational study examined higher education students (university and polytechnic) with MSK pain who attended direct access physiotherapy at Finnish Student Health Service (FSHS) between November 28, 2022, and May 31, 2023. Participants were recruited from all FSHS locations in Finland. Data were collected via four questionnaires: the Patient‐Specific Functional Scale (PSFS), the Short Form of the Örebro Musculoskeletal Pain Screening Questionnaire (ÖMPSQ‐SF), the Mental Health Index (MHI‐5), and the Experience of the Therapeutic Relationship. ÖMPSQ‐SF, MHI‐5, and PSFS were distributed via the FSHS online platform before the direct access physiotherapy visit, following the standard protocol of FSHS. Participation required digital consent, including approval for data collection. The Experience of the Therapeutic Relationship was assessed through a pseudonymized Surveypal questionnaire completed after the visit. Additional baseline data, including gender, FSHS region, study level, field of study, and age, were obtained from patient records. All questionnaires were completed independently outside the physiotherapy session.

Inclusion criteria were (a) attending direct access physiotherapy, (b) providing digital informed consent, and (c) completing the PSFS, ÖMPSQ‐SF, and MHI‐5 before the visit and the Experience of the Therapeutic Relationship questionnaire afterward. Exclusion criteria were (a) a physician‐referred physiotherapy visit, (b) refusal to provide consent, and (c) incomplete questionnaire data. Participants were fully informed about the study, and consent was verified through secure identification. The study followed the STROBE guidelines (von Elm et al. 2007).

Psychosocial burden was assessed using The Short Form of the Örebro Musculoskeletal Pain Screening Questionnaire (ÖMPSQ‐SF), a validated tool for screening for pain catastrophizing, fear‐avoidance beliefs, and symptoms of depression and anxiety (Linton et al. 2011; Ruokolainen et al. 2016). The ÖMPSQ‐SF is a shortened version of the original 25‐item Örebro Musculoskeletal Pain Screening Questionnaire (ÖMPSQ). The original ÖMPSQ has demonstrated moderate to good predictive ability in identifying patients at risk of persistent disability, with area under the curve (AUC) values ranging from 0.68 to 0.83 (Hockings et al. 2008). The shortened 10‐item version (ÖMPSQ‐SF) retains the predictive validity of the full version, with similar sensitivity (0.75 for both versions) and slightly differing specificity (0.78 for the short version and 0.84 for the long version) (Linton et al. 2011). The Finnish version of the ÖMPSQ‐SF has shown strong reliability, with intraclass correlation coefficients ranging from 0.59 to 0.96, and good construct validity (Ruokolainen et al. 2016).

The ÖMPSQ‐SF includes questions on pain duration (“How long have you had your current pain problem?” with scores ranging from 1 = 0–1 weeks to 10 ≥ 1 year), pain severity in the past week, ability to do light work for an hour, ability to sleep at night, tension or anxiety levels, feeling depressed in the past week, perceived risk of pain persistence, perceived likelihood of working normally in three months, whether increased pain signals a need to stop activity, and whether normal duties should be avoided due to pain. Responses were scored from 0 to 10, where 0 represents no impairment and 10 represents severe impairment. Scores were categorized as low (< 40), moderate (40–50), and high‐risk (> 50) (Linton et al. 2011; Simula et al. 2020) and analyzed as an ordinal variable. Pain chronicity was assessed using the ÖMPSQ‐SF question: “How long have you had your current pain problem?” A dichotomous variable was created, classifying pain lasting 12 weeks or more as chronic pain, and pain lasting 11 weeks or less as non‐chronic pain.

The Mental Health Index (MHI‐5) assesses psychological distress and is an effective screening tool for mood and anxiety disorders (Rumpf et al. 2001). Its psychometric properties have been found to be acceptable in the Finnish population, supporting its use in epidemiological research (Elovanio et al. 2020). Specifically, the MHI‐5 demonstrates good internal consistency (Cronbach's alpha = 0.89), an independent factor structure, and robust item characteristics (Elovanio et al. 2020). Moreover, the MHI‐5 has shown moderate predictive value for anxiety (AUC = 0.74) and good predictive value for depression (AUC = 0.90) (Berwick et al. 1991). Scores ranged from 0 (worst mental health) to 100 (best mental health). The five questions ask: “In the past 4 weeks, have you been a very nervous person?,” “Have you felt so down in the dumps that nothing could cheer you up?,” “Have you felt calm and peaceful?,” “Have you felt downhearted and low?,” and “Have you been a happy person?.” Responses use a five‐point scale (1 = all the time; 5 = none of the time). A score of 52 or lower was considered indicative of clinically relevant psychological distress, while a score above 52 indicated the absence of clinically relevant psychological distress (Parikka et al. 2022). For the analyses, the MHI‐5 was treated as a dichotomous variable.

Physical function was measured using the Patient‐Specific Functional Scale (PSFS), which assesses self‐reported activity limitations (Hall et al. 2011). Participants identified up to three activities they struggled with due to MSK pain and rated them on a scale from 0 (unable to perform the activity) to 10 (able to perform at pre‐injury levels). The total PSFS score was calculated as the mean of all activity scores and was treated as a continuous variable. PSFS has demonstrated sufficient concurrent, construct, and predictive validity, along with good to excellent reliability, with intraclass correlation coefficients (ICC) ranging from 0.76 to 0.97 across various MSK conditions (Abbott and Schmitt 2014; Horn et al. 2012). The Finnish version of the PSFS has also shown strong content validity (Pearson's r = 0.65) and responsiveness (Lehtola et al. 2013).

The Experience of the Therapeutic Relationship in‐house questionnaire was used to assess the patient's perspective on the therapeutic relationship in physiotherapy. It evaluates the therapeutic relationship across four key aspects: elements of the relationship, topics of conversation, trust, and patient involvement. The questionnaire is provided in Appendix 1. A minimum score of 4 indicated the best possible therapeutic relationship, while a maximum score of 20 represented the worst possible experience. The Experience of the Therapeutic Relationship score was used as a continuous variable in the regression analyses. The questions aim to identify the factors influencing the effectiveness of the therapeutic relationship as outlined in Bordin's (1979) theory, namely the emotional bond between the patient and the therapist, as well as a shared understanding of the goals and the means to achieve them (Bordin 1979). Moreover, the modified questions in this questionnaire align with constructs previously validated in several therapeutic relationship measures, such as the short version of Working Alliance Inventory (Hatcher and Gillaspy 2006), the Working Alliance Inventory Theory of Change Inventory (Hall et al. 2012) and the Session Rating Scale (Duncan et al. 2003). The instrument itself has not yet undergone formal psychometric validation. Plans are underway to conduct factor analysis and assess construct validity specifically within student populations and in the context of direct access physiotherapy.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Normality tests were performed using the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test for continuous variables and descriptive statistics were used to summarize patient characteristics. Categorical data are presented as numbers and percentages, while continuous data, as not normally distributed, are presented as medians and interquartile ranges (IQR). The dependent factor in the analyses was the Experience of the Therapeutic Relationship and independent factors were ÖMPSQ‐SF risk‐groups, MHI‐5 category, PSFS and pain chronicity. Activity limitations reported by participants (PSFS) were categorized into 11 groups for descriptive purposes: walking, sitting, squats and knee/hip movements, sleeping and resting, posture changes, stairs and inclines, daily tasks, sports and exercise, computer use and fine motor skills of the hand, standing and static postures, and other. Descriptive variables: study level (university/polytechnic), field of study (health and service; business and society; natural and medical sciences; technical; arts and humanities; undefined), FSHS region (south, east, west, central, north), gender, and age were also considered as independent variables at the first stage (see below).

The associations between the psychosocial factors, physical function, and pain chronicity and therapeutic relationship were analyzed using a multiple linear regression model. The Experience of the Therapeutic Relationship and PSFS were treated as continuous variables, meaning their actual numerical scores were used in the analyses. In contrast, ÖMPSQ‐SF, MHI‐5, and pain chronicity were treated as categorical variables, meaning they were grouped into categories rather than used as raw scores. To assess the robustness of the linear regression results, a sensitivity analysis was conducted using ordinal logistic regression, with the Experience of the Therapeutic Relationship score treated as an ordinal outcome. This model included the same predictors as the linear regression: MHI‐5, PSFS, ÖMPSQ‐SF risk group, and chronic pain.

Since the chronic pain variable was derived from the ÖMPSQ‐SF, we conducted two different models to avoid multicollinearity. In the first model, all independent variables (MHI‐5, ÖMPSQ‐SF, PSFS and descriptive variables), except chronic pain, were initially included in the linear regression model, with The Experience of the Therapeutic Relationship as the outcome. In the second model, all independent variables (MHI‐5, chronic pain, PSFS and descriptive variables) were included except for the ÖMPSQ‐SF. A backward elimination process was then used to remove nonsignificant variables one at a time.

As both the ÖMPSQ‐SF and the MHI‐5 include anxiety and depression domains, we conducted a sensitivity analysis in which we tested them in separate multivariate linear regression models. However, since the results were similar to those obtained from pooled models (data not shown), we decided to incorporate MHI‐5 into both final models. The results are reported as regression coefficients (ß) with 95% confidence intervals (CI). Analyses were conducted using IBM SPSS Statistics (versions 28 and 29.0.1.0) and Stata 17.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 326 students (median age of 26 years) with MSK pain attending direct access physiotherapy participated in the study. Of them, 69% (n = 224) were women. Sixty‐two percent were university students, while 38% attended polytechnic school. Additionally, 22% of the participants experienced clinically relevant psychological distress, and 17% of the students were classified as belonging to the ÖMPSQ‐SF high‐risk group at baseline. Chronic pain was prevalent among higher education students seeking direct access to physiotherapy, with 48% reporting this condition. The most common activity limitations affecting physical function reported by participants were sports and exercise (56%), walking (36%), and sitting (29%). Participant characteristics are presented in Table 1, and activity limitations are shown in Figure 1.

fn.p: Abbreviations: FSHS, Finnish Student Health Service; IQR, interquartile range; SD, standard deviation.
Pain lasting 12 weeks or more is classified as chronic pain.

ÖMPSQ‐SF: Short Form of the Örebro Musculoskeletal Pain Screening Questionnaire with scores ranging from 1 to 100, with 1 indicating the absence of psychosocial burden and 100 indicating high psychosocial burden (high‐risk > 50, moderate‐risk = 40–50, low‐risk < 40).
Psychological distress measured by the Mental Health Index (MHI‐5) with cut‐off point at 52 where “yes” < 52 points.

Physical function measured with the patient‐specific functional scale (PSFS), scale from 0 (unable to perform activity) to 10 (able to perform activity at the same level as before the injury or problem).

Therapeutic relationship measured with the Experience of the Therapeutic Relationship with a minimum score of 4 indicated a good therapeutic relationship, while a maximum score of 20 represented the worst possible experience.

caption.p: Activity limitations experienced by higher education students, measured using the Patient‐Specific Functional Scale.

sec.p: The therapeutic relationship was generally reported as very good (median 4, interquartile range 4–5). In this study, a minimum score of 4 indicated the best possible therapeutic relationship, while a maximum score of 20 represented the worst possible experience. Notably, 56% of participants rated the therapeutic relationship with the best possible score of 4, suggesting a substantial ceiling effect. The distribution was strongly skewed (skewness = 3.463). Psychological distress (ß = 0.30, 95% CI 0.03 to 0.58) and poorer self‐rated physical function (ß = −0.13, 95% CI −0.24 to −0.02) were associated with a more negative perception of the therapeutic relationship. In contrast, patient‐specific factors such as the presence of chronic pain and psychosocial burden were not significantly associated with the therapeutic relationship. The results are presented in Table 2 and visually summarized in the forest plot shown in Figure 2. Both linear regression models produced similar results for psychological distress and physical function; therefore, for the sake of simplicity, we report the results for these variables only from Model 1.

caption.p: The associations between patient‐specific factors and the therapeutic relationship.

Statistically significant results have been bolded.
Psychological distress measured by the Mental Health Index (MHI‐5) with cut‐off point at 52 where “yes” < 52 points.

Physical function measured with the patient‐specific functional scale (PSFS), scale from 0 (unable to perform activity) to 10 (able to perform activity at the same level as before the injury or problem).
Pain lasting less than 12 weeks is classified as non‐chronic pain.

caption.p: Associations of psychological distress, physical function, psychosocial burden and non‐chronic pain with the therapeutic relationship (multivariable regression, 95% CI).

sec.p: To account for the skewed distribution of the therapeutic relationship scores, we performed an ordinal logistic regression as a sensitivity analysis. Psychological distress remained significantly associated with a more negative perception of the therapeutic relationship (p = 0.015), confirming the main finding. However, self‐rated physical function was not statistically significant in the ordinal model (p = 0.402). Consistent with the main findings, other variables, including psychosocial burden and chronic pain, were also not statistically significant.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we explored whether patient‐specific factors, including psychosocial burden, psychological distress, self‐perceived physical function, and chronic pain, were associated with higher education students' perceptions of the therapeutic relationship in direct access physiotherapy. The findings suggested that psychological distress and lower self‐rated physical function were associated with a more negative perception of the therapeutic relationship. We are discussing these results in relation to previous studies in the field and Bordin's theory of the therapeutic relationship, which posits that its strength is based on both the agreement of goals and tasks and the bond between the patient and therapist (Bordin 1979).

The MHI‐5, a screening tool for psychological distress, was associated with a less favorable perception of the therapeutic relationship. Prior research suggests that patients' presence, receptiveness, genuineness, and commitment contribute to stronger therapeutic relationships (Miciak et al. 2018), but mental health symptoms may hinder these qualities due to fatigue, low self‐efficacy, and reduced engagement (Varela and Van Asselt 2022). The challenges of working with highly distressed patients have been well‐documented in psychotherapy research, as these situations require therapists to establish a shared treatment focus, actively engage the patient, foster a safe and productive relationship, and select appropriate therapeutic interventions (Smits et al. 2016). Similarly, MSK patients with psychological distress tend to have lower recovery expectations (Leech et al. 2023; Or et al. 2021), which can complicate goal setting and treatment adherence (Brunner et al. 2021).

In our study, the therapeutic relationship was not associated with psychosocial burden measured by the ÖMPSQ‐SF, in contrast to the MHI‐5. The ÖMPSQ‐SF was specifically developed to screen for risk‐factors related to MSK pain, such as pain catastrophizing, fear‐avoidance beliefs, and depressive and anxiety symptoms (Linton et al. 2011). One plausible explanation is that some of these factors, such as pain catastrophizing and fear‐avoidance behavior, are pain‐specific and therefore easier for physiotherapists to address through education and communication. In contrast, mood and anxiety disorders require a broader, more comprehensive approach, which physiotherapists may feel is beyond their professional expertise (Synnott et al. 2015; Unsgaard‐Tøndel and Søderstrøm 2022).

Indeed, a lack of confidence in treating MSK patients with psychological distress has been associated with weaker therapeutic relationships in previous research (Brunner et al. 2021). Additionally, physiotherapists' attitudes and skills may act as barriers (Driver et al. 2017). A systematic review of low back pain management found that physiotherapists often preferred addressing biomechanical aspects (Synnott et al. 2015). Structural barriers, such as time constraints, can further complicate this dynamic by forcing physiotherapists to prioritize physical care at the expense of psychosocial aspects (Driver et al. 2017). Feeling understood, respected, and validated by a physiotherapist strengthens the therapeutic bond (Gervais‐Hupé et al. 2024). However, forming such a bond in a direct access physiotherapy setting can be challenging. Direct access physiotherapists must not only manage complex disorders but also be competent in diagnosis, triage, and red flag screening while guiding the patient through their care (Vervaeke et al. 2023). Successfully balancing these demands while engaging with distressed MSK patients is crucial for a strong therapeutic relationship (Driver et al. 2017; Synnott et al. 2015). Addressing these challenges may require targeted training to enhance physiotherapists' confidence and skills in managing MSK patients with psychological distress, as well as in recognizing when to refer them to other healthcare professionals.

In our data, poorer self‐rated physical function was associated with a less favorable perception of the therapeutic relationship. This is an important finding as a strong therapeutic relationship is positively associated with exercise adherence and improved physical function in a physiotherapy setting (Holmes et al. 2023; Moore et al. 2020; Vestøl et al. 2020). This finding aligns with a previous study that found better physical function to be a predictor of a strong therapeutic relationship in patients with low back pain (Beneciuk et al. 2021). However, the same study did not observe this association among patients with knee pain (Beneciuk et al. 2021). We studied our data collectively and it remains unknown whether there would have been differences in pain sites and their association with the therapeutic relationship.

MSK patients' physiotherapy goals typically relate to physical function (Flynn et al. 2021). Understanding patients' expectations and priorities helps physiotherapists achieve agreement on goals and tasks (Flynn et al. 2021). In this study, the most common challenge in physical function was related to sports and exercise. It is possible that physiotherapists primarily focus on supporting students' ability to continue their studies, rather than addressing sports‐related concerns. Unmet expectations regarding treatment approaches may negatively affect the therapeutic relationship (Skatteboe et al. 2017). Aligning expectations with the primary focus of physiotherapy and setting realistic outcomes can improve satisfaction, strengthen the therapeutic relationship, and enhance recovery (Flynn et al. 2021; Gervais‐Hupé et al. 2024). Since expectations may shift after a single visit (Skatteboe et al. 2017), direct access physiotherapy plays a crucial role in shaping them. Patient education has been shown to strengthen the therapeutic relationship in MSK patients (Myers et al. 2022), suggesting that personalized education could further enhance patient engagement, especially for those with poor physical function.

In this study, 47% of the patients reported chronic pain, and we did not find an association between pain chronicity and the experience of the therapeutic relationship. There is evidence that a good therapeutic relationship is associated with improved pain outcomes (Kinney et al. 2020; Myers et al. 2022). Patients with chronic MSK pain have several needs regarding physiotherapy, such as support and encouragement to be understood and respected, and be given advice to enhance the self‐management of their pain (Gervais‐Hupé et al. 2024). Communication is one of the core competencies required of direct access physiotherapists (Vervaeke et al. 2023), and patient‐centered communication is particularly significant in fostering a strong therapeutic relationship (Babatunde et al. 2017; Myers et al. 2022; Vervaeke et al. 2023). Research has identified several communicative attributes that contribute to strengthening the therapeutic relationship, particularly with MSK patients. These include clarity of information, the provision of constructive feedback, the use of open‐ended questions, and active listening through pausing to allow patient expression (Babatunde et al. 2017; Gervais‐Hupé et al. 2024; Myers et al. 2022). In cases involving patients with chronic pain in direct access physiotherapy, communication may hold a uniquely critical role among the core competencies in establishing and maintaining an effective therapeutic relationship.

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations
sec.p: This study is to our knowledge the first to examine initial patient‐specific factors influencing the therapeutic alliance in direct access physiotherapy among higher education students. While patient‐centered care is fundamental to physiotherapy (Lin et al. 2020; Pinto et al. 2012), our findings highlight key considerations for treating students with MSK pain. The measurement tools (ÖMPSQ‐SF, MHI‐5, PSFS) used demonstrated strong reliability and validity, supporting their use in research and practice.

However, limitations exist. Comprehensive participant background data, such as general health status, pain location or severity, and prior treatment experiences is missing from our database, which might influence the interpretation. Moreover, the sample size was determined by the number of participants who gave their consent to be included in the study. This approach, while practical, should be considered a limitation, as the sample size was not calculated based on statistical power considerations and may have limited statistical power to detect smaller effects. The questionnaire assessing the therapeutic relationship, though adapted from validated tools, has not been formally validated and there are no data available about the potential clinically meaningful difference in terms of the score. However, many existing measures originate from psychology and lack validation for MSK pain populations (Araujo et al. 2017; Hall et al. 2012) and this study provides preliminary results for future research. The generally positive therapeutic relationships reported align with prior research, suggesting a ceiling effect and highlighting the need for further tool validation (Araujo et al. 2017; Hall et al. 2012).

The ceiling effect may have limited the model's ability to detect weaker associations. In a sensitivity analysis using ordinal regression, psychological distress remained significant, but physical function was no longer associated with the outcome. This suggests that the physical function finding may be sensitive to the analytical method and should be interpreted with caution. As such, results from this exploratory study will be used to inform further development of the questionnaire, with particular attention to minimizing potential ceiling effects and ensuring that it captures the unique features and needs of the student population within a direct access physiotherapy setting. Planned future work includes factor analysis and construct validation to assess its measurement properties in this specific clinical and demographic context.

To minimize bias, we recruited students from diverse backgrounds and adjusted analyses for significantly associated variables. Validated questionnaires reduced information bias, whereas pseudonymization mitigated response and social desirability bias. Recall bias was limited by collecting responses within 1 week of physiotherapy. However, we did not determine an a priori sample size due to participant availability, and self‐selection bias remains a concern. Despite efforts to reduce bias, residual confounding from unmeasured variables is possible.

sec.title: Implications of Physiotherapy Practice
sec.p: Psychological distress and poorer functional ability seem to be associated with a more negative perception of the therapeutic relationship among higher education students visiting direct access physiotherapy due to their MSK pain. Thus, screening and taking these factors into account in the patient‐centered care may be important, to serve better grounds for good therapeutic relationships. Further studies with a special focus on the clinical relevance of our preliminary observations are warranted.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: Research design: H.E.R., J.I.K., R.P.N., M.E.H. and A.J.H. Data collection: H.E.R. Data analysis: J.J.V. and H.E.R. Writing – original draft preparation: H.E.R. Contributed to manuscript writing and revisions: All authors. All authors reviewed and approved the final version.

sec.title: Ethics Statement
sec.p: All procedures were reviewed and approved by the University of Jyväskylä Ethical Committee on August 10, 2021 (157/13.00.04.00/2021).

sec.title: Consent
sec.p: The authors have nothing to report.

sec.title: Conflicts of Interest
sec.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We would like to thank the Finnish Student Health Service for the possibility of conducting this study, and a special thank you to the physiotherapists and students in FSHS for their active participation in the study. The authors acknowledge the use of Generative Artificial Intelligence ChatGPT (OpenAI) for language improvement in this manuscript. The AI tool was utilized for grammar checking, sentence structuring, and clarity enhancement. The final content was reviewed and approved by the authors to ensure accuracy and integrity. Open access publishing facilitated by Jyvaskylan yliopisto, as part of the Wiley ‐ FinELib agreement.

sec.title: Data Availability Statement
sec.p: The participants of this study did not give written consent for their data to be shared publicly, so due to the sensitive nature of the research supporting data is not available.

sec.title: Experience of Therapeutic Relationship
sec.p: This questionnaire measures the quality of a physiotherapy therapeutic relationship from the patient's perspective. Therapeutic relationship is evaluated from four different aspects: elements of relationship, topics of conversation, trust and patient involvement. Please rate your level of agreement with each statement.
The options are provided after each statement:
Strongly agree
Agree
Can't say
Disagree
Strongly disagree

sec.title: 1. Elements of Relationship:
sec.p: It was easy to communicate with the physiotherapist. I felt we achieved mutual understanding about my situation, and my therapist listened carefully to what I was saying.

sec.title: 2. Topics of Conversation:
sec.p: I felt like we talked about those topics that concern or are important to me. Our conversation helped me to understand my situation and rehabilitation better.

sec.title: 3. Trust:
sec.p: I trust my physiotherapist and I feel respected even if my view differs from my physiotherapist's opinion.

sec.title: 4. Patient Involvement:
sec.p: I have an active role in my rehabilitation and I'm fully committed to work toward the goals we have set.
